com.google.publicalerts.cap

Interface TrustStrategy

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    MockTrustStrategy

    public interface TrustStrategy
    Determines how stringently to validate digital signatures, and which PublicKeys are valid for such use.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean allowMissingSignatures()
      Return false if valid digital signatures are always required.
      boolean allowUntrustedCredentials()
      Return false if we must always have explicit trust in the credentials used to validate a digital signature (as defined by isKeyTrusted(java.security.PublicKey)).
      boolean isKeyTrusted(java.security.PublicKey key)
      Return true if the given PublicKey should be trusted in the context of validating the digital signatures of CAP alerts.

    • Method Detail

      • allowMissingSignatures

        boolean allowMissingSignatures()
        Return false if valid digital signatures are always required. Return true if a missing digital signature or Public Key should be tolerated. When both signature and Public Key are available, they will always be validated irrespective of this configuration setting.

      • allowUntrustedCredentials

        boolean allowUntrustedCredentials()
        Return false if we must always have explicit trust in the credentials used to validate a digital signature (as defined by isKeyTrusted(java.security.PublicKey)). Return true if untrusted credentials should be tolerated.

      • isKeyTrusted

        boolean isKeyTrusted(java.security.PublicKey key)
        Return true if the given PublicKey should be trusted in the context of validating the digital signatures of CAP alerts. Normally this would mean ensuring the PublicKey can be associated with an explicitly trusted 3rd party, e.g. via the use of X.509 certificates. Return false if the given PublicKey is not trusted. Note this method may be called irrespective of the return value of allowUntrustedCredentials()
